Award.AwardTitle: Graduate Student Tutorial and Winter Digitization Meetings, 2017

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Digitization is the representation of information in bits. This technology has reduced the cost of storage, computation, and transmission of data. Research on the economics of digitization examines whether and how digital technology changes markets. The NBER Digitization Project, launched in 2010, is building the foundations for an economics-oriented research community that examines the causes and consequences of digitization. This research community is young, and off to a good start. However, despite the importance of the topic, it is challenging to attract elite economic graduate students to do research on the topic. Among the many challenges, there is no standard reading list or courses in the area. Students are not exposed to frontier topics at formative times, when they are choosing dissertation topics. Many graduate students also lack visible ?role models? in their immediate environment, who pursue related topics. The project seeks to address this gap by bringing 50 graduate students to a two-day tutorial immediately preceding the winter meetings of the NBER digitization program in March 2017. The tutorial introduces graduate students to overviews of this young frontier area of research. In particular, the tutorial involves a combination of lectures by research leaders and small group discussions led by faculty. The students then attend the winter meetings of the NBER digitization program, which involves presentation of frontier research by six researchers and discussants. The project therefore gives graduate students exposure to a sampling of frontier research in this area, and enables them to have face-to-face time with research leaders. In this way, students are exposed to frontier topics and can identify visible role models.

Building a research community that studies the economics of digitization is important for effective Science and Innovation Policy. Such policy requires a deep understanding of the consequences of digitization for markets and for policy. By building this research community, PhD student workshops help develop a broader understanding of digitization and therefore directly contribute to the Science of Science and Innovation Policy. Digitization reduces some economic frictions and increases others. Understanding the underlying microeconomics of how the technology affects economic agents informs analysis of the welfare and policy implications. Areas of science and innovation policy related to digitization include (1) copyright, (2) software innovation, (3) big data, (4) digital platform regulation, (5) citizen science, (6) scientific communication, (7) communications infrastructure, (8) privacy, and others. Increasing research in the economics of digitization generates recognizable independent academic voices on these important areas of policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The digitization program advertised to attract students from a wide network of researchers, and succeeded in the following dimensions of the goals:

 

  • Held the events on February 28 and March 1st at Stanford SIEPR facilities. Then conducted the eighth winter digitization meeting on March 2nd. See http://papers.nber.org/sched/EoDs18.
  • Attracted 41 graduate students from 20 universities, primarily in North America. The best represented universities were Toronto (4), Cornell (4), CMU (3), MIT (3), and Stanford (3). Most students came from economics programs, and a group came from business or policy programs with analytical focus. One third (14) of the students were women.
  • The tutorial had four research presentations by Mike Smith, Judy Chevalier, Susan Athey, and Erik Brynjolfsson. Avi Goldfarb and Shane Greenstein made a presentation about the job market for digitization economists.
  • The winter digitization meeting had nine presentations by Jeremy Watson, Imke Reimers, Brett Hollenbeck, Chiara Farronato, Daniel Bjorkegren, Ariel Stern, Neil Thompson, Laurina Zhang, and Ananya Sen. Discussions were provided by Ben Shiller, Matthjis Wildenbeest, Judy Chevalier, Dina Mayzlin, Zoe Cullen, Sridhar Moorthy, and Abhishek Nagaraj.
  • Sent out a survey and had just over a 90% response rate (39 out of 43). The participants generally liked the choice of presenters, and liked being exposed to frontier work that they normally would not see in their graduate program. So we believe we accomplished our goal of placing many role models in front of them.  

 

What are the broader impacts of the proposed activity?

 

The digitization program held a tutorial for graduate students on a day and half before the NBER winter digitization meetings. 

 

  • The program attracted elite economic graduate students to do research on the topic.
  • Exposed students to frontier topics at formative times, and did so when they are choosing dissertation topics.
  • Exposed the broader community of researchers to students coming from settings where such communities did not exist.
  • Provided visible “role models” in their immediate environment, who pursue related topics.
  • We experienced stronger interest than anticipated. The program had to turn down 10 applicants due to lack of funds and issues with “fit.” Generally, these students were in their first year of graduate school.

 

Students who participated in the program over the years are now professors at Harvard, Toronto, Rochester, Toulouse, Arizona, Columbia, Indiana, U Washington, and Berkeley. Each of these former students (now professors) has research focused on the economics of digitization. We believe we have helped influence this new generation of research.
